To say that the "sum" is -1 is misleading. Addition is a particular mathematical operation, and extending that operation to infinite sums by the use of limits yields another mathematical operation, and this operation does not map the sequence (1,2,4,...) to -1. There is an operation that does that, and it is one that we intuitively understand as some sort of "summation", but it's not THE summation operation. When you don't clarify that, people have an everything-you-think-you-know-is-wrong moment where there's this concept that people have a strong intuitive understanding of - addition - and they learn something that apparently totally violates their understanding of it. So they have this feeling of having their minds blown, but really they're just confused because you've mislead them into believing that they no longer understand the fundamental rules of counting.

Ok, I know that this is "right", but it is also "wrong" at the same time. It is "right" because it is what is called analytic continuation of special functions. As an example, think about the Euler Gamma function. The Gamma function has a series representation (where it is represented as an infinite sum), that within a certain range, converges to a number (for the real part of the argument being greater than zero). It also obeys properties such as the reproductive property (Gamma(x+1)=x*Gamma(x)). Thus, one can analytically continue the Gamma function by simply saying that, if Gamma(x) is defined for Re(x)>0, then, it is also defined for Re(x)>-1, and it is simply given by Gamma(a)=Gamma(a+1)/a, where Re(a+1)>0, etc... The same kind of trick can be used with functions that have a series representation within a domain of convergence, like f(x)=1/(1-x), which can be represented by f(x)=1+x+x^2+x^3+... If one encounters the infinite sum representation of f(x), then, by "recognizing" the series expansion (by proving that within a certain domain, it corresponds to the series expansion of a certain function that it is also defined outside the domain), one can "call" the infinite sum function f(x) as simply f(x)=1/(1-x), and then, one can "evaluate the sum" outside the domain of convergence. Of course, all of this is "wrong" in the sense that, although the underlying function (which in many situations may be unknown) does exist outside the domain of convergence, it is no longer represented by the infinite sum (in the sense that its value cannot simply be approached by summing the terms of the sum in a sequential way). Thus, I would say that the explanation by minute physics is "morally correct", in the sense that there is such a thing as analytic continuation and it works in precisely this way, but "semantically incorrect" in the sense that the meaning of calling the series representation still a representation of the function even outside the range of convergence is unclear.

In computer science, it is. In binary, 2^n is just a bit shifted up by n. Therefore, the sum of 2^n is pretty much just setting n bits to 1. Because of the fact that computers are finite state machines, this series eventually converges on a threshold when it overflows to the signed bit, thus effectively subtracting -1(2^n) from 2^n, resulting in -1. Fun thing about computers, when they can't handle an accurate result, they converge on the most precise result and call it good.

I never said anything about multiplying Infinity.  Thats a whole different topic (for example, Infinity x 0 = Undefined.)  What you can't do is multiply an infinite series by a number.  For example: {1+2+3+4+5+6...} x 0.  The way you would do this with a finite set is to do, 1x0+2x0+3x0 etc.  But, because there are infinite elements of the set, you can never finish multiplying them all.  Thus, for any scalar a and any Infinite Series L, aL is undefined (no matter how much you want that to be 0.)

You can carry out a certain method of managing your partial sums such that you can fool yourself into coming up with a "sum" of 1/4, but all mathematicians (myself included) understand that this is just a trick.  Divergent series don't work that way.  We don't "throw it away."  We recognize that we didn't have anything to begin with.

No, it isn't equal to that in any sense.  It is the "infinity" variation of dividing by zero.  Such an action is undefined and simply imposing a value upon it is invalid.  The sum 1 - 1 + 1 - 1 ... is a divergent series and thus the "sum" of 1/2 or 0 (depending on how you rearrange your partial sums) is false.  The series doesn't "sum" to anything.  It diverges.

Mathematics isn't "retarded."  People who insist upon silliness being "real," however....

No, they're not well defined.  That's the entire point.  Divergent series can be manipulated to say anything you wish (and your series is wrong...you mean 1 + 2 + 4 + 8...) and your result there is not "valid" in a strict sense.  You cannot treat infinity as a regular number.

@Jamesa7171 But the thing is, you can arbitrarily choose which result you want. That's the way divergent series work. There's a thought experiment regarding counting which you can get to sum to any number you like since you're dealing with divergent series. This is nothing more than a variation of dividing by zero.

The point is that you're not cancelling. As the numbers get larger on the left, they are getting larger only half as fast on the right. You subtract the first numbers. It wouldn't be 2-2 (ignoring the -1), it would be 2-1. The next would be 4-2, the next would be 8-4. (by the way, you skipped 8)... @alephii You mean partial sums tends to infinity ? Yes of course, this is a divergent series.
The point here is that we have two functions :
f(x)=1+x+x^2+x^3+...
g(x)=1/(1-x)
We have f(x)=g(x) for all |x|<1. Outside this domain, f is not defined.
It MAY be useful (or not, depending on what you want to do) to extend the domain of definition of function f and to DEFINE f(x)=g(x) for all x. 
A definition can not be wrong, but it could be useless. This one is not.

The sum of this series (1+x+x^2+x^3) is S(x)=(1+x^(n+1))/(1-x). For the video x=2 and S(2)=Inf when n=Inf. If 0<x<1 the term x^(n+1) = 0 for n=infinity and the S becames S=1/(1-x) but again, only if 0<x<1. Have I missed something important? Seems clear for me that this video is wrong.

What I was saying though is that while yes, when you pick a finite n to stop at in the series, the answer is 2n-1 (because there is one last left over 2n there in the first doubled series), but the point of the video is that when you have n go to infinity, there is never a "2n" that isn't matched by a -2n since both of those series are infinite. If any of you complaining people would bother to expand a bit your knowledge, and look in Wikipedia, he would found out that there are many methods to deal with divergent series, such as Abel summation, Cesàro summation etc. In this particular case, the answer -1 is obtained from the analytic continuation to the complex plain of the generating function 1/(1-2x) which is equal to x+2x+4x^2+8x^3+... if |x|<1/2.
BTW, from the same reason, 1+1/2+1/3+1/4+...=-1/12, and 1+1+1+...=-1/2.
